question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::AccountAddress] [Script argument injection] Can an attacker inject addresses into script arguments to trigger false positives in account address matching, causing legitimate transactions to be blocked? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::AccountAddress] [Authenticator address extraction] Can the authenticator address matching logic be bypassed by using authenticator types that don't properly extract addresses? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_public_key()] [Key type mismatch] Can an attacker bypass public key filters by converting between key types (Ed25519, Secp256k1Ecdsa, Secp256r1Ecdsa, Keyless) that represent the same cryptographic key material? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: compare_ed25519_public_key()] [Incomplete key comparison] Does the function only compare Ed25519 keys and return false for other types, allowing non-Ed25519 keys to bypass filters that intended to block a specific key? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_public_key()] [MultiKey bypass] In MultiKey authenticators, if any key matches, does this allow attackers to include a blocked key alongside legitimate keys to bypass filters? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_public_key()] [Abstract authenticator bypass] Does returning false for Abstract authenticators mean that abstract account transactions can never be filtered by public key, creating a bypass vector? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_public_key()] [Fee payer key bypass] Can an attacker use a blocked public key as a fee payer while using a different key as the sender to bypass public key filters? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_public_key()] [NoAccountAuthenticator bypass] Does NoAccountAuthenticator always return false, allowing transactions without proper authentication to bypass public key filters? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [SingleKey address extraction] Can attackers craft SingleKey authenticators with manipulated public keys to extract arbitrary addresses, bypassing address-based filters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [MultiKey any logic] Does the any() iterator check allow attackers to include multiple public keys where only one needs to match, potentially bypassing filters by diluting the key set? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [Abstract function module exploitation] Can an attacker exploit the Abstract authenticator's module_address check to match arbitrary addresses by manipulating function_info? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_any_public_key_address()] [FederatedKeyless JWK manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate the jwk_addr field in FederatedKeyless public keys to match any target address, bypassing address filters? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_any_public_key_address()] [New key type bypass] If new AnyPublicKey variants are added in the future, will they default to false and bypass address matching filters? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_any_public_key_address()] [Keyless address bypass] Do Keyless public keys always return false for address matching, allowing keyless authentication to bypass all address-based filters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_address()] [MultiAgent secondary signer bypass] Can attackers bypass address filters by placing the target address in secondary_signer_addresses array rather than using it as the primary sender? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_address()] [FeePayer address confusion] Does the FeePayer authenticator check both fee_payer_address and fee_payer_signer separately, allowing attackers to exploit inconsistencies between these fields? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_address()] [Ed25519 authenticator bypass] Do Ed25519 and MultiEd25519 authenticators always return false for address matching, creating a significant filter bypass? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_address()] [Secondary signer iteration] Can the any() check on secondary_signers be exploited by including the target address in a large list of signers to trigger false positives? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_transaction_authenticator_address()] [SingleSender authentication] Does SingleSender properly delegate to account authenticator address matching, or can it be bypassed through type confusion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_multisig_address()] [Multisig address spoofing] Can an attacker craft a multisig transaction with a manipulated multisig_address field that doesn't correspond to the actual multisig account, bypassing multisig-based filters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_multisig_address()] [Payload V1 unwrap vulnerability] Does the unwrap_or(false) on the Option<AccountAddress> allow None multisig addresses to bypass filters? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_multisig_address()] [EncryptedPayload multisig extraction] Can malformed encrypted payloads with invalid extra_config cause multisig address matching to fail, allowing unauthorized transactions through? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_multisig_address()] [Non-multisig payload bypass] Does returning false for EntryFunction, Script, and ModuleBundle payloads mean these transaction types can never be filtered by multisig address? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_script_argument_address()] [Non-script payload bypass] Does returning false for EntryFunction, Multisig, and ModuleBundle payloads create a bypass where these transaction types ignore script argument filters? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: compare_script_argument_address()] [Argument type confusion] Can attackers bypass script argument address matching by encoding addresses as different TransactionArgument types (U8, U64, U128, Bool, Vector, etc.)? (High)
